awd_titl_txt: Nanostructured materials for photonics and spectroscopy
awd_abstract_narration:
Title: Materials with reduced dimensions for light detection.
Non-technical: Materials with a layered structure similar to graphite, where the atoms within each layer are strongly bonded, but the layers are weakly coupled and can be easily separated, have become the focus of intense research efforts worldwide. This is because it is now possible to reduce their thickness down to a few or even a single layer to create atomically thin devices or transparent conductors that are suitable for flexible substrates. However, the full potential of their drastic reduction in thickness and their new physical properties has not been realized. This project focuses on the study and applications of novel photodetectors based on graphene, a single layer of graphite, and single-layer MoS2. The PI will further reduce their dimensions by patterning single layers into structures that are just tens of nanometers wide, to create high-performance photodetectors that will work in the visible range, as well as in other regions of the electromagnetic spectrum, including terahertz radiation. Terahertz radiation comprises the electromagnetic spectrum between microwave and infrared radiation, in the frequency range between 100 GHz and 30 THz. Because it can penetrate through most plastics and non-conducting materials without the damaging ionization effects of x-rays, it has promising potential applications for security and medical imaging. Other applications include chemical fingerprinting (to identify chemical compounds), communication, either terrestrial short-range or between satellites, and imaging of blackbody radiation emitted by the landscape, to allow aircraft to land in conditions of poor visibility due to fog or smoke.  Notwithstanding the potential for application in many fields, terahertz technology is far from advanced, because powerful sources and sensitive detectors are scarce. This project builds on previous work by the PI demonstrating that nanometer-patterning of graphene yields terahertz detectors with extraordinary performance.
Technical: Graphene has material properties that are ideal for bolometric application: small electronic heat capacity and weak electron-phonon coupling, making it easy to create hot electrons with the incident electromagnetic radiation. This project will build on recent work by the PI who demonstrated that graphene quantum dots can yield extremely high-performance THz bolometers. This was done by measuring the current of hot electrons formed in the graphene source and drain electrodes and propagating through the graphene quantum dot. New work will extend the study to gated quantum dot bolometers to better understand the underlying physics of their extraordinary performance. This study will include the frequency and power dependence of their response and the coupling of these bolometers to antennas. In addition to graphene, hybrid structures based on graphene and MoS2 will also be investigated for hot-electron bolometer applications. Finally, this project will investigate detection of visible radiation in nanopatterned MoS2-based photosensors.

por.por_cntn:
This project studied the effect of drastically reduced dimensions on the optical response of atomically thin materials, including graphene, a single layer of carbon atoms, and monolayer semiconducting transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs), a layer of transition metal atoms (Mo, W) sandwiched between two layers of  chalcogen atoms (S, Se). The main focus was on the development of photodetectors fabricated by using these two-dimensional materials as channels in gated phototransistors and by reducing their dimensions even further, e.g. by fabricating graphene quantum dots or nanoribbons. This work demonstrated photodetectors with outstanding performance using large-area material that is compatible with scalable electronics, which is important to push applications of these two-dimensional materials beyond impractical small flakes exfoliated from bulk crystals. Studies on the effects of adsorbed molecules and defects on the device properties lead to the counterintuitive result that, in some cases, defective materials yield better performance. Specifically, defects introduced in graphene by the fabrication process (these defects can be introduced in a controlled way, by changing the fabrication process) change the cooling properties of light-generated hot electrons. The cooling dynamics is predicted to exhibit a characteristic cubic power law dependence on the electron temperature, markedly different from the quartic dependence predicted for pristine graphene. This different cooling mechanism yields graphene quantum dot detectors with smaller thermal conductance and higher responsivity. Since graphene does not have a bandgap, the remarkable device performance of the graphene quantum dots is ultrabroadband, from terahertz through telecom to ultraviolet radiation, with responsivity independent of wavelength.  

 For TMD phototransistors operating in ambient conditions, this project studied the effect of photogating from adsorbed molecules on the device response mechanism. Photogating occurs due to light-induced desorption of these molecules and is responsible for the high responsivity (> 10,000 A/W) of TMD photosensors. Wavelength-dependent studies showed that photogating occurs with photon energy smaller than the MoS2 bandgap, but larger than the energy needed to create bound electron-hole pairs (excitons). These findings explain why the response time of the photodetectors is quite slow, tens of seconds, very similar to the response time of MoS2 gas detectors, and why MoS2 photodetectors respond to light with photon energy smaller than the energy needed to excite free charge carriers.

This project also explored the use of highly sensitive photodetectors based on two-dimensional materials to study other nanoscale systems, single-molecule magnets (SMMs). These magnetic molecules are very promising for applications in high-density magnetic data storage, molecular spintronics and quantum computing.  SMMs are typically studied in bulk samples, but most applications require molecules deposited on surfaces, therefore it is important to understand whether the interaction with the surfaces may substantially alter the SMM properties. Graphene quantum dots are ideal candidates as highly sensitive photodetectors for in-situ electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopy of SMMs deposited on the graphene surface. Since EPR measurements are performed in the presence of magnetic field, this project studied the properties of the graphene quantum dots in magnetic field (including effects due to the formation of Landau levels) and showed that these devices are suitable for EPR measurements. This project also showed that the interaction between the SMMs and the graphene affects the transport properties of the quantum dot.

Beyond demonstrating high-performance devices using large-area materials that are more suitable for applications, this work also had a strong educational impact. It funded one graduate student full time and one graduate student part time. Two other graduate students carried out internships in National Laboratories, NIST and ARL, through the NSF INTERN program.  Four Georgetown University undergraduate students worked on topics related to this project for their senior thesis and four students from other institutions carried out research on two-dimensional materials within the summer NSF REU program hosted by Georgetown University. The students gained skills on a broad range of experimental techniques, including CVD growth of two-dimensional materials, device fabrication by e-beam and photolithography, optical and electronic characterization measurements from room temperature to cryogenic temperatures. 

The results of this work have been disseminated with 6 peer-reviewed journal publications, 13 invited and 14 contributed talks at international conferences, 2 Ph.D. thesis, and 4 undergraduate senior thesis for B. S. degree. 1 US patent was also awarded to the graphene quantum dot detectors.

Infrastructure developed during this project will also have an impact on future research at Georgetown University. It includes a home-built stacking station to fabricate heterostructures of two-dimensional materials, a home-built optical set-up to be attached to a cryostat for photoluminescence measurements of two-dimensional materials at cryogenic temperature and a new sample holder for EPR measurements of single molecule magnets with the graphene quantum dots.
